model.name: Cloud Native Architecture
model.documentation: Cloud Native Architectural Models using Archi. Contains models for CAAS, Cloud Native Applications, 12/15 Factor Applications with CI/CD/CS, monitoring and log management. Infrastructure components include Red Hat OpenShift, Red Hat Storage, Red Hat Cloudforms, Red Hat JBoss Middleware.

view.name: System Context
Component Model
Deployment Model: Data Center View OCP 3.x On-Premise Reference Architecture (OCP, CF, CNS)

node.label: All nodes can be RHEL or RHEL Atomic however it is recommended that OCP Application Nodes are RHEL Atomic.
All master, infrastructure and application nodes have network connectivity between each other.
Public IPs are assigned to restricted to key entry points.

Red Hat OpenShift On Premise Reference Architecture.
The toplogy used in the reference architecture consists of a single Red Hat OpenShift (OCP) instance and Red Hat Container Native Storage (CNS) instance deployed in a single data center.

The OCP Metrics and Logging (EFK) feature requires containers to be deployed on block storage. Fault tolerant logging requires 3 containers. In this topology, it would be 3 containers across 3 racks. Metrics and Logging is nosted on the OCP Infrastructure node.
Red Hat CNS is used to store container images.
Red Hat CNS is used to provide container persistent volumes.
Red Hat CNS runs within the OCP Infrastructure Nodes. One CNS instance is deployed in each rack.
The container build and CI/CD Jenkins environment is hosted on the OCP Application Nodes.
OCP Application Nodes will host all the containers for the application. That may consist of the application, database, integration middleware and others.
OCP comes with a load balancer. However you can use F5 or other supported options.
Instances should be at a minimum to be 4 vCPU with at least 32 gb of ram and 40 gb of disk. See documentation for more details.
RH Storage App Nodes support application storage needs.
RH Storage Inf Nodes support OCP infrastructure needs (image registry, metrics, logging).

view.name: Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (DevSecOps) Detail on OpenShift with Jenkins

node.label: Static Code Anaysis and Unit Testing JUnit, Sonarqube, Selenium

Software Component Management Sonatype Nexus
Binary Security Scanning BlackDuck
Integration and Business Scenario Testing Cucumber
Registry Security Scanning Red Hat Quay

view.name: Deployment Model: RH OpenShift 3.x + RH Virtualization + RH Storage

node.label: Red Hat OpenShift + Red Hat Virtualization + Red Hat Storage
Items to address: Software provisioning, Software Distribution, Patch Management, Asset Inventory, Service Desk, Infrastructure Monitoring, Log Aggregication

view.name: Deployment Model: Data Center View OCP 3.x Detail with Web Traffic (Phase 2 )
Deployment Model: Disaster Recovery using Red Hat Container Ready Storage

node.label:
Architecture: We use the OCP AWS Reference Architecture as the template to build the OCP clusters. We have 2 OCP clusters (one in AWS Region 1 and another in AWS Region 2) and 2 Red Hat CNS clusters (one in AWS Region 1 and another in AWS Region 2) and Ansible Tower.
Problem: You need to move 3 items to recover an OCP environment. You need compute/projects, networking and storage.
Answer: First we need to enable replication of storage. We can use RH CRS to geo-replicate container images, volumes and PVs to the 2nd OCP cluster. Next we export compute by using OCP day 2 scripts to export all the OCP project details and then use the OCP day 2 scripts to import the project into the OCP cluster in AWS Region 2. Finally for networking we use manual or Ansible to switch the load balancer to point to AWS Region 2. Steps 1 and 2 can be done on a periodic basis before the disaster recovery event.

view.name: Deployment Model: Data Center View OCP 3.x Detail with Web Traffic (Phase 1)
Deployment Model: Data Center View OCP 3.x AWS Reference Architecture (OCP, CF, CNS)

node.label: All master, infrastructure and application nodes have network connectivity between each other.
Public IPs are assigned to restricted to key entry points.

Red Hat OpenShift AWS Reference Architecture.
The toplogy used in the reference architecture consists of a single Red Hat OpenShift (OCP) instance and Red Hat Container Native Storage (CNS) instance deployed in a single region with nodes spread across 3 availability zones for resilience.
AWS Infrastructure Components: https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/reference_architectures/2018/html/deploying_and_managing_openshift_3.9_on_amazon_web_services/components_and_considerations#aws_infrastructure_components AWS Charge Model: https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/reference_architectures/2018/html/deploying_and_managing_openshift_3.9_on_amazon_web_services/components_and_considerations#aws_infrastructure_charge_model

The OCP Metrics and Logging (EFK) feature requires containers to be deployed on block storage. Fault tolerant logging requires 3 containers. In this topology, it would be 3 containers across 3 AWS AZs. Metrics and Logging is nosted on the OCP Infrastructure node.
Red Hat CNS is used to store container images.
Red Hat CNS is used to provide container persistent volumes.
Red Hat Storage is backed by AWS EBS and can draw from AWS EBS if more storage is needed.
Red Hat CNS runs within the OCP Infrastructure Nodes. One CNS instance is deployed in each AWS Availability Zone.
The container build and CI/CD Jenkins environment is hosted on the OCP Application Nodes.
OCP Application Nodes will host all the containers for the application. That may consist of the application, database, integration middleware and others.
RH Storage App Nodes are to support application needs.
RH Storage Inf Nodes are to support OCP infrastructure needs (image registry, metric, logging).

view.name: Deployment Model: Data Center View OCP 3.x Detail
view.documentation:
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/reference_architectures/2017/html-single/deploying_and_managing_openshift_container_platform_3.6_on_amazon_web_services/
Hosts 2 baston (t2.micro) 3 OCP master (no cost with OCP, m4.xlarge) 3 OCP infrastructure (no cost with OCP, m4.xlarge) 6 OCP application (12 cores of OCP, t2.large) 6 Cloudforms (no cost with OCP, m4.xlarge) 3 Storage (i3.xlarge) 6 Ansible Tower (m4.xlarge) 3 Satellite (i3.xlarge) == Lab -> 26 "infastructure" hosts to support OCP + 6 OCP application hosts = 32 hosts Non production -> 26 "infastructure" hosts to support OCP + 6 OCP application hosts = 32 hosts Production with DR -> 26 "infastructure" hosts to support OCP + 6 OCP application hosts + 3 additional storage (another AWS region, other public cloud or on premises data center) + 1 Ansible Tower DR + 1 Satellite Server = 37 hosts
AWS VPC Networking Refer to reference architecture. More may be needed for Ansible, Cloudforms, Red Hat Storage and Red Hat Satellite.
AWS Security Group Refer to reference architecture. More may be needed for Ansible, Cloudforms, Red Hat Storage and Red Hat Satellite.

node.label: All OCP master, OCP infrastructure and OCP application nodes have network connectivity between each other.
Public IPs are assigned to restricted to key entry points.

Cloud Native Architecture based off of Red Hat OpenShift AWS Reference Architecture.
The toplogy used in this architecture consists of a single Red Hat OpenShift instance deployed in a single region with master and infrastructure nodes spread across 3 availability zones for resilience.
When in disaster recovery, the master's node data (script), external certificates (scripts), AWS objects (scripts), storage (RH Storage) needs to be exported to another region. Red Hat Cloudforms and Red Hat Ansible automation scripts can help with cold or warm DR.
Data will be replicated peer to peer by RH Storage. When more capacity or performance is needed, we can up the EC2 instance type or draw on more storage via AWS EBS.
Red Hat Storage will draw storage from AWS EBS.
OCP master and OCP infrastructure Nodes are m4.xlarge (4 vCPU, 16gb mem) on RHEL.
Bastion is t2.micro (1 vCPU, 1gb mem) on RHEL.

Application container are t2.large (2 vCPU, 8gb mem) on RHEL Atomic. With 6 nodes, you have a total capacity of 48gb. Most containers are 2gb therefore 24 containers can be moving across 3 zones.
Application containers can be used to host applications, building new containers, RH Single Sign On, Jenkins server (CI/CD), JBoss middleware, databases and any other docker based containers.
Used for executing disaster recovery and other automation scripts. Ansible Tower instances are m4.xlarge (4 vCPU, 16gb mem) on RHEL. Future: Containerization.
Satellite Capsule instances are i3.xlarge (4 vCPU, 30.5gb mem, 1tb SSD) storage optimized on RHEL.
Red Hat Satellite agents and Insights agents installed on all RHEL based hosts.
Cloudforms instances are m4.xlarge (4 vCPU, 16gb mem). Future: Containerization.
Storage instances are m4.2xlarge (8 vCPU, 32gb mem) on RHEL.
To replicate data off region for disaster recovery, there is a group of 3 Red Hat Storage servers somewhere else (other AWS region, other public cloud or on premises data center).
OCP master nodes are replicas of each other and are synced via peer to peer.
VPN connection between remote data center and AWS.
Generally speaking, each Cloudforms instance can support 400 EC2 instances.
Generally speaking, each RH Storage host can support 400 client connections.

The OCP Metrics and Logging (ELK) feature requires containers to be deployed with block storage. Fault tolerant logging requires 3 containers. In this topology, it would be 3 containers across 3 AWS AZs.
You can easily add add more container capacity by adding more OCP Application Nodes.
VMs and Red Hat OpenShift can live side-by-side. The Red Hat management layer can manage both container and VMs.
DR is constantly receiving storage and installation/patch media to help meet RPO of 1 hour and RTO of 4 hours.
OCP aggregated logging stack (EFK), the OCP metrics stack runs on the OCP Infrastructure node.

view.name: Deployment Model: Disaster Recovery

node.label:
Architecture: We use the OCP AWS Reference Architecture as the template to build the OCP clusters. We have 2 OCP clusters (one in AWS Region 1 and another in AWS Region 2) and 2 Red Hat CNS clusters (one in AWS Region 1 and another in AWS Region 2) and Ansible Tower.
Problem: You need to move 3 items to recover an OCP environment. You need compute/projects, networking and storage.
Answer: Backup all the project files and project data from the 1st OCP cluster and then restore that in the 2nd OCP cluster.

view.name: Deployment Model: Node View
Deployment Model: Data Center View OCP 3.x AWS Reference Architecture

node.label: Master Nodes are replicas of each other and are synced via peer to peer.
All master, infrastructure and application nodes have network connectivity between each other.
Public IPs are assigned to restricted to key entry points.

Red Hat OpenShift AWS Reference Architecture.
The toplogy used in the reference architecture consists of a single Red Hat OpenShift instance deployed in a single region with master and infrastructure nodes spread across 3 availability zones for resilience.
When in disaster recovery, the master's node data (script), nfs (AWS EFS), block (AWS EBS) and object storage (AWS S3) needs to be exported to another region. Red Hat Cloudforms and Red Hat Ansible automation scripts can help with cold or warm DR.

The OCP Metrics and Logging (EFK) feature requires containers to be deployed on block storage. Fault tolerant logging requires 3 containers. In this topology, it would be 3 containers across 3 AWS AZs. Metrics and Logging is nosted on the Infrastructure node.
AWS S3 storage is used to store container images.
AWS EFS is used to provide container persistent volumes.

view.name: Deployment Model: OpenShift 3.x and external database

node.label: Applications are hosted within an OpenShift Node. When needed, the applications will connect to a remote instance (outside of OpenShift cluster) of Couchbase.

Developers will use the OpenShift self service dashboard to provision their applications, middleware and databases.
At this time, Couchbase provisioning within OpenShift does not exist. This will require development of this integration.
There will be 3X of the above. The OpenShift reference architecture recommends the OpenShift cluster to be spread across 3 physical/virtual data centers for high availability.

view.name: Process Model: Continuous Deployment

node.label: Canary or blue/green deployment? Deployment Driven by CI/CD pipeline? How much is automated vs. manual?
What is in pipeline? Functional Testing? App/Infra Security Testing? Operations Testing? Performance Testing? Resiliancy Testing?
1. Download team code 2. Write test 3. Write code 4. Pass test 5. Merge to team code
- On checkin to Team Source Code 1. Tag, Pull and Build Code 2. Push image to Team Docker Regsitry 3. Pull Image and Test Code 4. Tag/Promote Container Image
- When ready 1. Pull Container Image 2. Run Container Image
- When ready 1. Pull Container Image 2. Run Container Image

view.name: Component Model: Cloud Native Applications Software

node.label: Continuous Integration, Continuous Deployment, Continuous Security
Understand how the code is running. Products: Zipkin, CNCF Jaeger. More info can be found at http://opentracing.io/documentation/pages/supported-tracers.
Typically there are rules in applications and should be highly modifiable. Products: Red Hat JBoss Business Rule Engine: drools, optaplanner.
Most people build software using the JavaEE or Spring Framework with opinionated Spring Boot or Wildfly Swarm.
Think hashtable across mutiple servers data store. Products: MongoDB.
Think arrays on a single server data store. Products: PostgreSQL, MariaDB.
In memory data store; caching. Products: Red Hat JBoss Data Grid, Infinispan, Memcache, Redis.
Make mutiple data sources look like 1 data source. Products: Red Hat JBoss Data Virtualization, teiid.
Distributed messaging using a shared log. Products: Apache Kafka.
Transform messages, route messages and mediate protocals. Products: Red Hat JBoss Fuse, Apache Camel.
Distributed messaging using one to many or one to one queues. Products: Red Hat JBoss AMQ, Apache ActiveMQ.
Automate the build to deploy pipeline. Products: Jenkins, Spinnaker.
Document issues, problems and tasks. Products: JIRA.
A way for people to share assets. Products: GIT.
A place to store compiled file or deployed artifacts. Products: Sonatype Nexus.
Software to help build a product. Products: Apache Maven.
Documentation on how to use the API. Products: Swagger
Aggregating logs from mutiple systems into a single dashboard. Products: ELK, EFK.
IT Monitoring items below the application. Products: Prometheus, Nagios, Zabbix.
Automate all the things with push button self service dashboard. Products: Ansible Tower.
Code the web experience. Products: Angular.
Measure the code being developed by your developers. Products: SolarQube.
Test your system to the latest patches and meet organization compliance. Products: OpenSCAP.
Test your system to the latest patches and meet organization compliance. Products: OWASP Jenkins Plugin, Arachni.
Scripting to automate all of IT. Products: Ansible for compute, storage, network. Fastlane for mobile.
Functional testing of your code. Products: JUnit, Cucumber (BDD)
Robot testing of the functional features of your website. Products: Selenium.
Communication for your team. Products: Rocket.Chat, Slack.
Interact with IT systems as if it was a person. Products: Hubot.
Robot to make sure that developer code to best practices. More tools at https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Source_Code_Analysis_Tools
Provide inbound and outbound connectivity using REST, SOAP, MQ, Kafka.
Products: Hive, Tez, Pig, Storm, Spark, HBase, Accumulo, Solr
Robot testing of the NFR features of your system. Products: Chaos Monkey.
Handle a lot of real time data being thrown into the system. Products: Apache NiFi.
Process the data in real time. Products: Kafka.
Core framework features like dependency injection, transaction management.
Ability to throttle, protect, scale and montize API calls. Products: 3Scale.
Tool to help you write code. Products: Red Hat JBoss Developer Studio
Opinionated distributed messaging. Products: Istio, Linkerd, Envoy, Conduit.
Robot testing of the performance NFRs features of your system. Products: JMeter, Gattling.
Think double linked list data store. Products: neo4j.
Moving copies of master data to other systems. Products: Talend.
Keep software systems up to date. Products: Red Hat Satellite, Red Hat Ansible.
Monitor application, compute, storage and networking. Products: Red Hat Cloudforms.
Ensure systems are meeting organization compliance and stop rouge IT. Products: Red Hat Cloudforms.
Create new operation system hosts. Products: Red Hat Satellite, Red Hat Ansible.
Automate compute, storage and networking. Products: Red Hat Ansible.
Provision out network and network devices. Products: OpenvSwitch, haproxy.
Provision file, block and object storage. Products: Red Hat Storage.
Run applications without the underlying complexity. Products: Red Hat OpenShift.
Provide self serivce infrastructure. Products: Red Hat Openstack.
Running mutiple hosts on a single machine. Products: Red Hat Virtualization.
Tracking web marketing. Products: Google Analytics.
Login and access to what resources. Products: Red Hat Single Sign On, Red Hat Identity Management.

view.name: System Context: Cloud Native Applications
Component Model: Cloud Native Applications Data Centric

node.label: Server replication of key/value or objects is a standard feature in Red Hat JBoss Data Grid.
Red Hat JBoss Data Virtualization does not have any sync features.
Would need ETL software to support server replication.
Server replication is usually a stand feature of NoSQL database products.

This diagram was created to visually explain how data can be synced across mutiple datacenters.
Imagine there is a requirement to send data from data center A to data center B and that servers in each data center are “active” and are serving applications within their datacenter. There are several different methods to perform the "sync".
Queues are never synced across data centers. In Red Hat JBoss AMQ, queues have to configured to “forward” messages between servers to move the data.
Log based messaging are never synced across data centers. If you want to store a piece of data across mutiple datacenters, the data has to be sent to each data center.

view.name: Deployment Model
Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment (CI CD) on OpenShift with Jenkins

node.label:
Topology
You have 3 projects that represent 3 different environments. You build your application once in the development environment and Jenkins deploys that application across the development, staging and production project.

view.name: Component Model: Cloud Native Applications

node.label: All stateful information is stored in cache or database
Common types of database are relational or NoSQL databases.
Common types of messaging are queue based or log based messaging.
Databases usually store operational or reference data. If storing reference data, this would be a master data.
Common types of caches are application level (memory grid) or database level (data virtualization) caches.
